data.sampled:
Based on the contract specifications provided, the option strategy being implemented is called the "Calendar Spread" or "Diagonal Spread."

The Calendar Spread involves selling two at-the-money options with the same strike price but different expiration dates and buying one option with a lower strike price and a different expiration date. This strategy is designed to profit from different paths the underlying stock price can take between expiration dates, while keeping the overall risk low due to the offsetting positions.

In the given options, the put and call options have the same strike price and expiration dates, which means they are both at-the-money options. Therefore, it can be inferred that the strategy is to take advantage of both the bullish and bearish movements of the underlying stock by selling a lower strike call option and buying a higher strike put option, with the hope of finding a delta of between -0.05 and 0.05.

Given the delta of [-0.05], this strategy is called a "Long Call Write" or "Long Put Right Write." It seeks to profit from a rising or falling stock price between the two expiration dates by buying (selling) call (put) options with higher (lower) strike prices. The net position for this strategy consists of a long underlying call with a narrow delta, offset by a short underlying put with a wide delta, resulting in a neutral overall position.

Overall, this strategy involves selling options to hedge against potential price movements and buying options to take advantage of potential price movements, with the goal of generating income while maintaining overall portfolio balance.

data.sampled: The given option strategy is called a Calendar spread. It aims to benefit from a partial protection against a general decline in the market while also hedging against potential price gains. The sale of the short put option allows the investor to limit losses if the market plummets, while the purchase of the long call option gives the investor the potential to profit if the market rises. The purchase of the short call option gives the investor protection from further price losses, while the purchase of the long put option can limit potential gains. The expirations are chosen to align with the typical trading horizon of this type of strategy.

By selling the $130 put option for $0.23, you will have $23.00 left over, which can be used to purchase more shares at $127. In this case, the stock price will be $131.00 ($130 stock price + $1.00 gained from the put).

By buying the $170 call option for $0.20, you will be able to avoid the $10.00 cost if the stock price reaches $170.00. The call option has a intrinsic value of $0.00, so you will have no loss if the option is not executed. In this case, you will have made a profit of $0.90 on the call option.

data.sampled: This is an arbitrage strategy. You are simultaneously long one call and short one put and long one call and short one put. This strategy is used when one asset has reached its fundamental limit of production and is expected to decrease in price, and another asset has already been produced and is expected to increase in price. In this case, you expect the price of oil to decrease and the price of the underlying stock to increase.

data.sampled: Based on the given option strategies, it is an "Out-of-The-Money (OTM) Call Buy-Write/ write-put Options" strategy. The strategy involves selling 1 put option with a strike price of $80. Buy-write options are also known as write-put options because they are sold with the intention of buying (writing) an equivalent put option with a higher strike price before the expiration date. Based on the given expirations, this strategy is OTM because the stock price is less than the strike price of the options. The buy-write portion of the strategy is implemented by selling 1 call option with a strike price of $83 to purchase 1 put option with a strike price of $80. The aim is to profit from a decrease in the stock price before the expiration date. The strategy is OTM for the same reason as the buy-write portion. The remaining options are sell 1 call option with a strike price of $85 to purchase 1 put option with a strike price of $78. This strategy aims to profit from a potential increase in the stock price before the expiration date. The strategy is also OTM because the stock price is less than the strike price of the options. Overall, this strategy is an OTM buy-write/ write-put options strategy with the aim of profiting from potential price movements of the underlying stock before the expiration dates.

data.sampled:
Based on the given option contracts, the option strategy being implemented is a bear put spread. This strategy seeks to profit from a decline in the price of the underlying asset. The options sold, the $27 strike price put and $25 strike price put, have the same expiration date and are sold at the same price, which is $0.3. This means that the options are being sold with a $0.3 premium, which will be paid to the seller if the asset price falls below $27 per share at expiration.

Similarly, the options bought, the $33 strike price call and $34 strike price call, have the same expiration date and are bought at the same price, which is $0.21. This means that the options are being purchased with a $0.21 discount, which will be paid to the buyer if the asset price exceeds $33 per share at expiration.

Therefore, the overall strategy seeks to profit from a decline in the price of the underlying asset. By buying one $25 strike price put and one $33 strike price call and selling one $27 strike price put and one $34 strike price call, the options seller is betting that the asset price will fall between $25 and $33 per share at expiration. If the price falls below $25 per share, the seller will make the $0.3 premium, while if the price rises above $33 per share, the seller will incur a $0.3 loss. By buying one $25 strike price put and one $34 strike price call and selling one $27 strike price put and one $33 strike price call, the options buyer is similarly betting that the asset price will fall between $25 and $33 per share at expiration.
